Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Aquatic Sciences Research at the School of Freshwater Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration: This award provides renewed funding for a Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of Wisconsin - Milwaukee's School of Freshwater Sciences (SFS). The proposed program would provide 10 students with a 10-week active learning experience each summer for two years. The Site provides environmental aquatic science research training for nationally-recruited students in a cohesive, multi- and interdisciplinary environment. Students interested in physics, chemistry, geology, and biology of lake and ocean settings are paired with mentors supervising active, often interdisciplinary research laboratories. Together they develop a program of empirical study compatible with the advisor's interests and capabilities within one of the dynamic interdisciplinary research programs. After an introduction to SFS, students spend a day of offshore Lake Michigan sampling experience, a day of analytical and conceptual interaction, and a second day of ROV exploration on a nearby reef aboard the research vessel R/V Neeskay. They then write a short research proposal and begin a combined field, laboratory, and library investigation. In some cases, small teams of students (2-3 each) work within an umbrella project. Scientific seminars and workshops on graduate school, career options and opportunities, writing and public presentation of results and related topics are included in the program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal goal was to provide nationally-recruited college undergraduates with an in-depth, highly hands-on experiential internship in Aquatic Science-related Science-Technology-Engineering-Mathematics (STEM) disciplines. Another overarching goal was to facilitate: active participation in field and/or laboratory based research; exposure to career path options; instruction in competitive practices for education and employment; development of peer-to-peer and scientist-student support and networking; and interaction with students in other programs.

       Objectives of the program were to inclusively expose students in mainly STEM college degree programs to the wonders of professional life in Ocean Sciences. Specific objectives spanned both hard science (research, investigation, synthesis, reporting) and soft skills (peer mentoring, interpersonal networking, handling foreign environments, speaking skills, efficient use of limited financial resources for living and research, others). Among these objectives, all successfully met, were life-changing experiences for many students. Quantitatively, 100% of the REU fellows wrote a research proposal, learned literature research techniques, learned practical laboratory skills, collected natural samples in the field for their studies, prepared and analyzed the samples according to their proposal, calculated the outcome of the experiments, wrote the findings in a scientific-format paper, presented a poster to a public audience, and interacted with other students in related programs presenting in the same symposium.

      During the first week, a series of laboratory safety instructions provided participants with certificates in chemical hygiene, radiation safety, animal care and use, and other appropriate areas. In addition, the REU students experienced the joys of inhabiting brand new laboratory facilities, some still partially under construction. During the project period a total of 15 Lake Michigan expeditions were undertaken spanning a range-from-port of 3 to 35 miles, an endurance of 7 to 22 hours, and procedures involving nearly every Ocean Science disciplinary activity except deep coring. During the summer there were presentations by Professional Science Master's students describing their internships in water industry through members of the Water Council, and thesis defenses of Thesis Master's students. A suite of workshops, brown bag lunches, and other socio-academic activities were offered. The overwhelming effort, for 28 years, was however devoted to REU student research in their own laboratories.

       After each session, a broad-scope "Undergraduate Research Symposium" included as many as 16 undergraduates (10 REU) working separately together on an umbrella project of aquatic nature. The REU Site provided a suite of academic and skill-development opportunities that embraced individuals and linked individuals through interdisciplinary projects and thought. The students presented posters from REU (Research Experience for Undergraduates), UBM (Undergraduate BioMath), BHEF (Business Higher Education Forum), McNair (Ronald E. McNair Postbaccalaureate Achievement Program), SURF (Support for Undergraduate Research Fellows), and independent research origins.
